clinical_study.brief_title: Metallosis on Tissues and Serum Metal Levels in Children
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Metallosis on Tissues and Serum Metal Levels in Children With Orthopedic Implants

brief_summary.textblock: Slightly elevated blood metal levels have been found in adults undergoing hip and knee replacement. It is unknown whether pediatric patients with metal implant(plates/screws/rods) have elevated blood metal levels. This may have an impact on practice if children have high blood metal levels with routine orthopedic implants. If researchers find elevated metal levels, they may recommend patients to have the plates removed or may switch to a different type of metal. Further work on this topic is needed.

primary_outcome.measure: Mechanistic responses of bone repair cells upon Ti exposure
primary_outcome.description: To address how deregulated bone repair provokes adverse reactions, the investigators will monitor gene regulatory effects in cell culture models of titanium exposure by either silencing or activating key biological pathways

secondary_outcome.measure: Evaluate serum levels of metal ions
secondary_outcome.description: To evaluate systemic effects of metal ions on children, the investigators will determine whether metal ion levels are elevated in participants with retained implants by intraoperatively blood draw and at first postoperatively visit. Conversely, participants undergoing implant placement will also have ion levels taken intraoperatively and then at latest follow-up visit to see if implants cause in increase in serum metal levels

arm_group.description: 10 patients with stainless steel devices implanted
30 patients with titanium or titanium-alloy implanted devices
10 patients undergoing de novo titanium implant placement who have had no previous orthopedic procedures

biospec_descr.textblock: Waste Surgical Tissue, possible cell-line development

study_pop.textblock: Pediatric patients undergoing orthopedic surgery to remove or place metal implants.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Ages 4 years - 18 years
- Stainless steel, titanium or titanium-alloy based implants, scheduled for surgery
- De novo surgery where titanium implant placement
Exclusion Criteria:
- Concomitant infection
